title: China’s Sinopec to acquire stake in Russian petrochemical firm Sibur
text:
China’s Sinopec to acquire stake in Russian petrochemical firm Sibur 7 September 2015 Print Email 
Chinese state-owned oil and petrochemical giant Sinopec has signed a framework investment agreement to acquire a stake in Russia-based gas processing and petrochemicals company Sibur. 
Signed during Russia President Vladimir Putin's visit to China, the deal is expected to further strengthen the companies' presence, and the partnership between Russia and China. 
Sinopec said that Sibur's vertically-integrated upstream and petrochemicals business model complements its operations. 
Last year, Sibur recorded revenues of RUR361bn ($5.4bn). 
A source from Sibur was quoted by Reuters as saying that Sinopec could purchase a stake of over 10% in the Russian company. 
The source added: "The deal will not lead to serious changes in the shareholding structure." "This transaction is in-line with our objective to strategically expand our petrochemical business overseas." 
Sinopec chairman Wang Yupu said: "This transaction is in-line with our objective to strategically expand our petrochemical business overseas. 
"Our continued partnership will help diversify and secure Sinopec's long-term sourcing of petrochemical products." 
Subject to regulatory approvals, the transaction is expected to be concluded by this December. 
Sibur chairman Leonid Mikhelson said: "This transaction with Sinopec is a clear signal of confidence from a global energy and chemical industry leader in Sibur's high-quality asset base and future growth potential." 
Mikhelson will continue to be the largest shareholder of Sibur. Other stakeholders include businessman and billionaire Gennady Timchenko, and Sibur managers.
